story: Director IIT Kharagpur shared National Digital Library of India's post.
message: Director IIT Kharagpur shared National Digital Library of India's post. “Ask the right questions, and nature will open the doors to her secrets” A precocious and gifted student, Sir C V Raman, passed his matriculation at 11 and his F.A., with a scholarship, at 13. A Gold Medal for a Bachelors in Physics at the Presidency University Madras was followed by a Master of Sciences with the highest distinction. Pursuit of the sciences brought him to academia in KOLKATA and thus began what he would fondly refer to as the golden era of his career. He continued his research at the Indian Association for the Cultivation of Sciences (IACS) of which he was also the Honorary secretary. It was IACS that Raman led experiments, along with K S Krishnan, on the scattering of light, and discovering what came to be known as the Raman effect. This discovery of immense importance soon garnered him recognition and fame and plaudits of the scientific community all over the world including enthusiastic mentions by the ‘father of nuclear physics’ Ernest Rutherford. He was soon conferred a knighthood and numerous awards. In receiving the Nobel Prize for #physics in 1930 he became the first Asian and non-european to receive the Nobel in the sciences. #CVRaman had and continues to spark the imagination of the scientific community of India till this day. He was born #OTD in 1888. We honour him with a glimpse of his life and works sourced from the Raman Research Institute: http://bit.ly/2AaMPTu #Tribute #Birthday #NuclearPhysics #Stalwart #LearnShareGrow

message: Prof Soumya K Ghosh, Department of Computer Sc & Engineering IIT Kharagpur has been awarded National Geospatial Chair Professorship of the Department of Science and Technology, Government of India. Heartiest Congratulations to Prof Ghosh.

Prof Soumya K Ghosh, Department of Computer Sc & Engineering IIT Kharagpur has been awarded National Geospatial Chair Professorship of the Department of Science and Technology, Government of India. Heartiest Congratulations to Prof Ghosh.

“It has been decided that there will be no common engineering exam next year. However, the idea has not been completely discarded. The AICTE will submit a report about feasibility of conducting the exam in future,” a senior official said.
